title: How to Make Honey Mustard

steps.headline: Combine all of the ingredients in a small mixing bowl.
steps.description:
Place ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of honey, ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of mayonnaise, ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of Dijon mustard, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar, and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of cayenne pepper into the bowl. Make sure the bowl is big enough that the ingredients won't overflow once you start stirring. Use store-bought mayonnaise or make your own with eggs, olive oil, and vinegar for a fresher alternative. Honey Mustard Variations
If you like a little more heat, use spicy mustard instead of Dijon mustard. Or mix in a little bit of hot sauce. For a creamier sauce, increase the amount of mayonnaise you add. If you love Indian food, add a pinch of curry powder to the honey mustard. For a healthier honey mustard sauce, swap Greek yogurt for the mayonnaise. It will make the sauce a little tangier, but will also lower the fat content and increase the protein.

steps.headline: Use a whisk to mix the ingredients together.
steps.description: Rotate the bowl with one hand as you whisk the sauce in a circular motion with the other. Continue beating until all of the ingredients are thoroughly blended. If you don't have a whisk, use the tines of a fork to mimic the same motion. You can also use a blender to combine the ingredients.

steps.headline: Place the sauce in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 2 weeks.
steps.description:
Seal the container tightly to prevent the honey mustard from going bad faster. Get rid of it if you see mold spots or if it starts to smell. You may need to stir the sauce right before you use it if it's separated. How to Use Your Honey Mustard Sauce
Marinade meat in the honey mustard before grilling or baking. Use it as a dip for chicken fingers, fries, corn dogs, and more. Thin it out with a little bit of water to toss with mixed greens. Drizzle it in a wrap for a tasty lunch. Smear it on crackers or pretzels. Package the honey mustard in pretty jars to give as gifts.

steps.headline: Combine all of the ingredients in a 16 oz (450 g) glass jar.
steps.description:
Add ⁄3 cup (79 ml) of olive oil, 1 cup (240 ml) of honey, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of whole grain or coarse-ground mustard, 3 teaspoons (15 ml) of fresh-squeezed lemon juice, and 3 teaspoons (15 ml) of minced garlic into the jar. Use a jar that can hold at least 2 cups (470 ml) of liquid. A standard mason jar will work. You can also use a plastic container that has an airtight lid. Homemade Coarse-Ground Mustard Recipe
Ingredients:
6 tablespoons (89 ml) of mustard seed⁄2 cup (120 ml) of water1.5 tablespoons (22 ml) of white wine vinegar⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of salt⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 ml) of turmeric2 tablespoons (30 ml) of sugar
Directions:
Grind the mustard seed with a mortar and pestle as you slowly pour in the water. Then add the remaining ingredients and grind them until combined. Store the mustard in an airtight container for up to 1 year in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Seal the jar and shake it vigorously to mix up the dressing.
steps.description: This helps distribute all of the ingredients evenly in the oil so the dressing is infused with plenty of flavor. Shake it until everything is thoroughly combined. If you're using a container that doesn't shake well, use a whisk to stir the ingredients together.

steps.headline: Store the dressing in the fridge for up to 3 weeks.
steps.description: Make sure you seal the jar tightly after each use to keep it fresh for longer. It's normal for the dressing to separate while it sits, but if you notice mold or a funky odor, throw it away. Shake the dressing immediately before you're ready to use it. The vinaigrette is best served at room temperature, so let it sit out for 15 to 30 minutes before using it.
